raw_response:
<translation>
When Nāmakaokapāo‘o finished his prayer, at that moment Puali‘i struck him on the top of the head with a chisel, causing it to split and the brains to spill upon Puali‘i, and the head spoke out from that place. The head of Puali‘i spoke to Nāmakaokapāo‘o, saying: "Farewell, O Nāmakaokapāo‘o." Nāmakaokapāo‘o then picked up the head of Puali‘i and cast it into the waters of Waipouli, a cave on the seashore of Honouliuli, five miles distant.
</translation>

---

<commentary>
**Paragraph 9:**

• This section constitutes a dramatic climactic moment in the narrative of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o, marked by a supernatural transformation and deeply rooted cultural symbolism. The depiction of post-mortem speech from the head of the decapitated Pua-li‘i introduces an esoteric and possibly shamanic element, consistent with motifs found in many ancient Hawaiian chants (*mele*) and origin stories, particularly those associated with demigods, healers, or Kahiko-era traditions;  

• The sequence begins with: *A pau ka pule āna ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o* (“When Nāmakaokapāo‘o finished his prayer”) – indicating that Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o was engaged in a sacred activity—perhaps invoking protection, divine guidance, or spiritual fortitude prior to the confrontation. The prayer (*pule*) in Hawaiian tradition often served to align oneself with the ancestral and divine forces before undertaking any significant act, physical or metaphysical;  

• *I ia wā i ‘o‘oki ai ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi i luna pono o Nāmakaokapāo‘o* – “At that moment, Puali‘i struck him with a chisel on the top of the head” – The *ko‘ilipi* (chisel) used by Puali‘i suggests a stone or bone tool of symbolic significance—possibly a *pōhaku ki‘i* (carving stone or adze) or a bone implement used in ritualistic contexts, such as in *pīnī‘au* (bone-setting) or *anāna / lāʻau lapaʻau* (traditional healing). That such an instrument was used in this act underscores the ritual-like nature of the incident, perhaps resembling a spiritual balancing (*pono*) or *kānāwai* (justice/retaliation) governed by the old laws and divine mandates;  

• *E ho‘ohuli aku ā nā ‘oi o ke ko‘i iā Puali‘i, moku ke po‘o, a ‘ōlelo mai i kahi ‘ē* – “…so that the brains spattered upon Puali‘i, and the head spoke from that place” – The severing and scattering of intellect (*loi*) symbolizes more than just violence—it marks a disruption in mana (*supernatural power*) and the release of spirit (*uhane*) into the metaphysical realm. The fact that the decapitated head *still speaks* is a powerful narrative device suggesting the persistence of spirit in the Hawaiian cosmology; that consciousness continues beyond the physical body is a belief upheld in various accounts involving *‘unihipili* (spirit bodies) and *aumākua* (ancestral deities). The head (*po‘o*) is considered a sacred part of the human being, sometimes kept as a *ho‘ohāloa pūhana* (spirit guardian) or used in *hānau ho‘okani* (rebirth rituals for others);  

– **Etymology Analysis**: The name *Pua-li‘i* is significant. *Pua* is a root suggesting origin, beginning, or ancestry (as in *puāwai*—source of water or blood). *Li‘i* means small or noble, suggesting lineage in royal or *ali‘i* bloodline standing. The name may imply a noble origin descended from a source or ancestral wellspring; however, Pua-li‘i in this story represents regression to old, violent practices rather than moral refinement—possibly alluding to the regression seen in the tensions of the post-'Ai Kapu era, when figures of former power sought to restore old traditions at the expense of new moral frameworks;  

• *Pane mai ke po‘o o Puali‘i iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Aloha ‘oe, e Nāmakaokapāo‘o.”* – “The head of Puali‘i spoke to Nāmakaokapāo‘o, saying: ‘Farewell, O Nāmakaokapāo‘o.’” – The farewell (*aloha ‘oe*) at death is a formal recognition of passage, transformation, or transcendence. Here, the *po‘o* itself serves as a literal and metaphorical mouthpiece conveying ancestral wisdom or judgment from the other side. The spiritual hierarchy of head over body is reversed momentarily, with the head attaining power in death that it lacked in life;

– Some interpretations draw from the broader motif of *ka po‘o ‘ōlelo aku nei* (“speaking head”) in Polynesian mythology, where the separation of the head from the body emphasizes *kanaka waiho*—man abandoned—while the head becomes a vessel for lingering knowledge or truth;

• *Lālau akula ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke po‘o o Puali‘i a kiola akula i kai o Waipouli, he ana ma kahakai o Honouliuli, ‘o kona loa, ‘elima mile ka loa.* – “…Nāmakaokapāo‘o then picked up the head of Puali‘i and cast it into the waters of Waipouli, a cave on the seashore of Honouliuli, five miles distant.” – The casting of the head into the water is a symbolic conclusion to the life of Pua-li‘i. Water (*wai*) and especially caves (*ana*) are ritual spaces of transformation and kūpuna veneration in Hawaiian cosmology. *Waipouli* (“dark water” or “deep water”) located on the seacoast of *Hono-uliuli* (“dark bay”), further locates this moment in sacred, shadowed space — often a zone associated with spirits and liminality in ancestral traditions;

– **Symbolism of Distance**: The distance—five miles (*elima mile*)—may carry numerological or symbolic weight. The number five (*elimā*) frequently appears in Hawaiian tradition, associated with the cycle of the moon (five *āina kai* phases), the body (*po‘o, lima ‘elima*), and ritualized offerings. This may signify a metaphysical separation, that Pua-li‘i's *uhane* is guided across not only physical terrain but across cosmic thresholds;  

• Allegorical Interpretation: Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s journey continues, now carrying with it the *po‘o* of Pua-liʻi, echoing the mythic structures in the *mo‘olelo papahele* (legendary tales) of heroic children with divine links (e.g., Kai-hi*-ka*-moku, Pele, Māui) who overcome obstacles, often with symbolic deaths leading to new kinds of spiritual power or social truths. The head of Pua-li‘i is discarded at Honouliuli, near the site of earlier tension—the cooked ulua and sweet potato misguidedly served as substitution for proper *'ai kapu* practice—the act of throwing the head into a cave by the sea may symbolize a final rejection of the past practices. Water becomes both purifier and agent of finality; it accepts spiritual remains while preventing their lingering over the land and its people.  

</commentary>
reference_translation: When Nāmakaokapāo‘o ended his prayer, Puali‘i  struck at Nāmakaokapāo‘o with the adze right on  top of his head, but the blade of the adze turned  towards Puali‘i and his head was cut off. From a  distance, the head of Puali‘i said to   Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Goodbye, Nāmakaokapāo‘o.”  Nāmakaokapāo‘o took the head of Puali‘i and  threw it in the sea at Waipouli, a cave on the  beach at Honouliuli, which was five miles long.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 9:**• While the abandonment of the ‘Ai Kapu and the rise  of Christianity are historical, Pua-li‘i’s attack of Nā- maka-o-ka-pāo‘o does not seem to have a correlating  historical reference. The ‘Ai Kapu was abandoned in  1819 and the first Christian missionaries arrived in  Hawai‘i in 1820, with a full year in the interum of no  organized religion to replace the ‘Ai Kapu. While  many Hawaiians were stubbon to adopt Christianity  and resented it, Christianity spread quickly and  overwhelmed any pro-‘Ai Kapu sentiment by the end  of the 1820s. If Pua-li‘i here represents the ‘Ai Kapu  and Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o represents Christianity, and  the adoption of Western culture in a more broad  sense, this event in the story seems to misrepresent  the ‘Ai Kapu as savage, impulsive, and violent against  Christianity, culminating in a single event. There is no  such historical single event recorded in history;  • By a twist of fate, the adze Pua-li‘i wielded to cut off  the head of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o somehow turned  against the wielder, cutting off the head of Pua-li‘i,  which Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o tossed into the ocean at Wai-pouli (water of darkness), a cave in Hono-uliuli  (bay of darkness) in ‘Ewa, O‘ahu, a distance of five   miles away. This ironic demise of Pua-li‘i signifies the  ultimate defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu by Christianity and/or  progressive ambitions, but this violent event has no  parallel in Hawaiian history. This could be viewed as  an embellishment as a type of Christian progaganda.  • The five-mile long toss of Pua-li‘i’s head by  Nāmakaokapāo‘o was an emphasis on the boy’s  superhuman physical strength.
